description:
This interdisciplinary course focuses on the global interconnectedness of memory and forms of memorialization in the 20th and 21st centuries and their reflection in the English-speaking world.
It discusses landmark historical moments and the varied forms of memorialization that historical events imply, together with their cultural and political consequences. The course also analyzes the affective implications of tragic events and catastrophes upon individuals or entire communities. 
Focusing on the Holocaust, the apartheid regime in South Africa, the Rwandan genocide, the NATO intervention in Kosovo, 9/11 and Hurricane Katrina, the course examines forms of global memory, activism and the ethical turn that contemporary texts present us with. 
       The course also traces critical positions/interventions and landmark genre transformations in the literary canon of the English-speaking world. By introducing students to various types of primary materials (literary texts, documentaries, films, historical documents, newspaper articles), the course familiarizes them with key concepts in history, memory and affect studies; at the same time, it undertakes a close reading of the literary and visual texts presented.
     Cultural background of the texts (literary, visual) discussed will lead to an enhanced knowledge of the literary periods covered and the cultural landscape in the English-speaking world in general, thereby complementing (but not overlapping with) other literature-oriented and theory-oriented courses.

syllabus:
Instructor: Ioana Luca

E-mail: ioanaluca.ntnu@yahoo.com    

Global Memories, Memories of the Global

Department of English, NTNU, Spring 2016

**_Course description_**

       This interdisciplinary course focuses on the global interconnectedness of memory and forms of memorialization in the 20th and 21st centuries and their reflection in the English**\-**speaking world. It discusses landmark historical moments and the varied forms of memorialization that historical events imply, together with their cultural and political consequences. The course also analyzes the affective implications of tragic events and catastrophes upon individuals or entire communities. Focusing on the Holocaust, Hiroshima, the apartheid regime in South Africa, the NATO intervention in Kosovo, and 9/11, the course examines forms of global memory, activism and the ethical turn that contemporary texts present us with. The course also traces critical positions/interventions and landmark genre transformations in the literary canon of the English-speaking world. By introducing students to various types of primary materials (literary texts, autobiographies, graphic narratives, documentaries, films, historical documents), the course familiarizes them with key concepts in history, memory and affect studies; at the same time, it undertakes a close reading of the literary and visual texts presented. The cultural background of the texts (literary, visual) discussed will lead to an enhanced knowledge of the literary periods covered and the cultural landscape in the English-speaking world in general, thereby complementing (but not overlapping with) other literature-oriented and theory-oriented courses.

**_Objectives_**

The main goals of the course are the following:

1.      To offer students in-depth knowledge of the historical moments and forms of memorialization discussed, as well as their global ramifications;

2.      To familiarize students with forms of memorialization and their affective implications (mourning and grief), as well as their implications at national, regional and global scale;

3.      To familiarize students with concepts such as “lieux de memoire,” “collective memory,” “cultural memory,” “postmemory”  “affect,” “structures of feeling,” etc.

**_Textbooks_**

Course pack

Handouts & lecture notes on Moodle [http://moodle.ntnu.edu.tw/](http://moodle.ntnu.edu.tw/)

**_Course requirements_**

Students are expected to be familiar with the required readings prior to class discussions. Students will be graded on the basis of (1) their active participation in class 20% (2) moodle activity 10%, (3) individual response papers/presentations 20%, (4) research paper at the end of the term 50%. Failure to attend classes and meet the above mentioned requirements will result in the student inability to pass the exam.  Late assignments are **NOT** accepted.

**_Academic Dishonesty_**

Academic dishonesty is defined as but not limited to plagiarism, cheating, misrepresenting one’s work, and forging documentation. Academic dishonesty is a serious matter. Any student who plagiarizes or cheats will fail the course.
